awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CDI Type II: Dynamics and Control of Cardiac Tissue
awd_abstract_narration:
Complex spatiotemporal dynamics underlie many arrhythmic disorders of the heart. Despite decades of biomedical research and the development of increasingly detailed computational models, the mechanisms that induce and sustain these arrhythmias remain elusive. We seek to improve our fundamental understanding of these mechanisms by developing a radical and urgently needed paradigm shift from computationally intensive direct numerical simulations to a description of cardiac dynamics in terms of a finite repertoire of spatiotemporal patterns. Using cutting-edge numerical algorithms, we will compute a hierarchy of exact steady and time-periodic solutions of detailed ionic models of cardiac dynamics. These unstable solutions describe cardiac dynamics in terms of a finite repertoire of spatiotemporal patterns that are currently hidden from view. Their determination for fully resolved cardiac tissue models is computationally intensive, but once these solutions are obtained, they yield a radically new understanding of the spatiotemporally chaotic dynamics as a walk through a repertoire of corresponding recurrent patterns. This representation also allows development of nonlinear control of cardiac dynamics using electrical stimulation that may require lower voltages than current defibrillation approaches. Numerical computations will be tightly integrated with experiments involving both cardiac tissue and cell cultures. The experiments will be used both to validate the proposed computational analysis and to test the control approach.

Cardiac arrhythmias are a major cause of mortality in the industrialized world, and any reduction in their incidence derived from a deeper understanding of their behavior could have a significant societal impact. By combining state-of-the-art numerical, analytical, and experimental approaches to the study of cardiac tissue, this project aims to initiate a radical paradigm shift: we propose to use direct numerical simulation as a tool to develop a new kind of quantitative template description of the dynamics of cardiac tissue. In this approach, the dynamics of arrhythmias is understood as a set of possible transitions between different cardiac rhythms, leading not only to a deeper dynamical understanding of the initiation and evolution of cardiac arrhythmias, but also to improved strategies for their prevention or termination. Although the focus is on cardiac dynamics, the methods developed will impact other fields dealing with high-dimensional complex systems that exhibit unstable recurrent patterns, such as neural disorders, dynamics of fluids and plasmas, and climate studies.

por.por_cntn:
Cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial and ventricular fibrillation, are a major source of mortality in the industrialized world. They represent an uncoordinated pattern of contractions that leads to a severe, and often lethal, disruption of the cardiac function. The lack of fundamental understanding of the mechanisms that lead to initiation and maintenance of arrhythmias remain a major hurdle for prevention and treatment protocols. The goal of our research was to develop a qualitative and quantitative framework that could be used to better understand, describe, and, ultimately, eliminate arrhythmic behaviors. Fibrillation is an example of a more general phenomenon - spatiotemporal chaos - which is a dynamical regime typical of spatially distributed complex systems such as fluid flows or animal brains. In the case of cardiac tissue, contraction is controlled by electrochemical excitation waves, and spatiotemporal chaos manifests as complicated patterns that feature multiple rotating spirals that move, break up, and reconnect in an apparently random and unpredictable fashion. 

We have discovered that these complicated motions are, in fact, not random but are organized by the motion of, and interaction between, the topological objects - spiral cores - that can be thought of as instantaneous origins about which individual spirals rotate. Spiral waves mediate the interactions between the cores, much as electromagnetic waves mediate interactions between electric charges. In this way the global pattern and its dynamics can be reduced to local structures and local interactions, yielding a dramatically simplified description capable of yielding novel insights into the role played by the excitability and heterogeneity of cardiac tissue in fibrillation as well as defibrillation. Therefore, our results are of immediate practical relevance for medicine (e.g., improving ablation surgery techniques) and biomedical engineering (e.g., designing a new generation of smart pacemakers and defibrillators). In addition, these results also contribute to the development of our arsenal of mathematical tools. In particular, we have shown that the mathematical framework that underlies the dynamical description of cardiac arrhythmias is strongly influenced by the local symmetries - translation or rotation of the tissue. These symmetries are responsible not only for the spiral shape of the excitation waves, but also strongly affect their drift and interactions with neighboring spirals. 

Although cardiac arrhythmias were both the focus of, and the motivation for this research, more broadly our discoveries have changed the way we think about other complex systems which display spatiotemporal chaos. In particular, the idea of using local symmetries to understand interactions between dynamical structures gives rise to a new way of thinking about fluid turbulence. Our cardiac research is thus inspiring several profoundly new ways of describing turbulence  - a problem often considered the greatest unsolved problem in physics. This research has directly contributed to training of three graduate students and five postdoctoral researchers. It has provided a highly diverse and interdisciplinary environment essential for training the next generation of researchers and exposed them to a broad array of numerical and analytical tools required for solving complex interdisciplinary problems in science, medicine, and engineering.
